text: Today we're going to do Leyland numbers.

(Brady: Leyland numbers?)
- Which are really str-

(Have you heard of the Leyland brothers?)
- No, who are they?

(In Australia they used to
have a TV show,)

(like in the 70s and 80s,
and they'd just go)
(on adventures around Australia and show)

(you cool stuff.)
- 'Ask the Leyland brothers is
the name of this new series. And that's
exactly what we'd like you to do - ask us

whatever it is you'd
like to see, right Mike?

That's right, Mal.' 
- (When you say Leyland)
(numbers I think of the Leyland brothers.)

Well, there's two numbers
so one
for each, right? So here's a Leyland

number for you, let me just- it's 
named after

Paul Leyland who's an Oxford.
- (Ohh, see)
(the Leyland brothers were Mike and Mal.)

- Not Paul?
- (No)
If I've got two numbers x

and y, a Leyland number is x
to the power y
plus y to the power x. The only condition
on this is that x and y must be bigger
than 1, that's my only condition.

(And they can't be 1?)
- No they can't be 1s. So one
has got to be less than y and, by
convention, you said that y is less than
or equal to x. Because it's x to the

power y plus y to the 
power x, if you- you'd
just be double counting the other
way around so you- just by convention you
pick one to be smaller than or equal to
the other. What's the first few numbers?
well, if I just sort of have x and y here

and then we just say what the Leyland
number is, well-
so the first one is going to be, if if x-
if y and x have to be bigger than 1 the
first thing that can be is 2. So if
they're each equal to 2 then the Leyland
number is 2 to the power 2 plus 2 to the
power 2, and that's 4 plus 4 which is 8.
And now if I- what am I doing? I'm saying
y is always less than or equal to x. So
if I let x be 3 and y be 2 then it's
3 to the power 2 plus 2 to the power
3, so this is equal to 9 plus 8 which is
17. You can just go through them, I mean
you can just- you just build them up. Here
you've got 32,
and then we've got 54, and we've got 57,
and you've got 100 - and they just go on.
So- but the particular class of numbers
that I believe are quite of interest to
people, of course, are the primes.

'It's a long way on a day like today,

Although this is recreational maths at
it's best, that is, you know, where you
just go and have some- play around with
the numbers. I think this technique
is actually used to try and actually
determine wha- as a way of determining
whether some things are primes or not.
And because there's basically just this
nice combination of x to the y plus y to
the x. So the particular class that are
of interest are Leyland primes; not just
your generic Leyland number but your
Leyland prime which- prime numbers made
out of this combination. We've met

our first one, 17 is our
first Leyland prime,
and it's of course 3 squared plus 2
cubed. And then- they're not that
frequent, right, so 593 is made up of
9 squared plus 2 to the power 9, that's a
prime, and then we've got 32993,
that's made up of 15 squared plus 2 to
the power 15; and you can go on right?
2097593 is made up
of 21 squared plus 2 to power 21; and in
fact- so what are the biggest right?
Up to November of 2012 the largest prime-

(Largest Leyland prime?)
- Largest Leyland prime, yeah - it's
considerably smaller than the largest
prime - was the following one; but just

the way- the way it works right? 
The way it
breaks down is so neat is: 5122 to the
power 6753, plus of course then it's
to the power 5122; and this is a
number which has a mere twenty five

thousand and fifty digits.

(out for us?)

let's not waste out effort
on that one, why don't
we go to the one which was discovered in

that was made up of 8- it's 8656 to the
power 2929, plus 2929 to the
power 8656. And this is a number that
consists of 30,000 digits. So you've got
your- the interest just because they're
fun things to play with, and they- but
they are used as a diagnostic to try and
help determine whether something's likely
to be a prime or not. Using- because
of the fact that it splits
into this x to the y plus y to the x,
it's a an additional tool that people

make use of, which is quite nice.
